title: Which Bible verses made you an atheist? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Which Bible verses made you an atheist?” There were many verses that, combined, caused me to think the Bible could not be the word of God. Here are a few examples, and explanations as to why they convinced me the Bible is not the word of God, and that it is written by ancient primitives: James 1:13-15 New International Version (NIV) 13 When tempted, no one should say, “God is tempting me.” For God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does he tempt anyone; 14 but each person is tempted when they are dragged away by their own evil desire and enticed. 15 Then, after desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, gives birth to death. The above is contradictory, and exposes the god of the Bible as not very smart. If God designed humans, he is the reason they have desires to begin with. So, God actually is tempting people in a roundabout way. He also created the temptations (ie. The Fruit of the Knowledge of Good and Evil, etc.). The authors of the Bible fell far short of perfection when inventing their god. The reason this verse exposes the biblical god as unintelligent, is that any thinking person who is God would say, “Since I cannot be tempted by evil, and do not tempt others, and since I am designing angels and men in my own image, I will create them so that they too are not tempted by evil, and so they will not tempt anyone. If my character does not allow me to sin, then I will make it a part of angel’s and mankind’s nature to not be tempted by evil, so that sin, death, and suffering will not enter the world I created, and I will not have to dish out death, suffering, and eternal torture. Their character will not allow them to sin, and they will be just as happy as I am about not wanting to sin.” That God does not do so in the Bible is the result of the fact that evil does exist, and there must be some way to account for it when creating a God. If you invent a God that does what any thinking person would do, he wouldn’t be compatible with the obvious facts about life and suffering. Here is another passage that makes me doubt the Bible is the word of God: Matthew 5:18-19 New International Version (NIV) 18 For truly I tell you, until heaven and earth disappear, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until everything is accomplished. 19 Therefore anyone who sets aside one of the least of these commands and teaches others accordingly will be called least in the kingdom of heaven, but whoever practices and teaches these commands will be called great in the kingdom of heaven. The Law is morally atrocious, as depicted in the Old Testament, and would land people in jail if they actually obeyed it. Here are a few more passages that cause me to doubt the Bible: Revelation 14:11 New International Version (NIV) 11 And the smoke of their torment will rise for ever and ever. There will be no rest day or night for those who worship the beast and its image,or for anyone who receives the mark of its name.” Matthew 25:46 New International Version (NIV) 46 “Then they will go away to eternal punishment, but the righteous to eternal life.” Mark 9:47-48 New International Version (NIV) 47 And if your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into hell, 48 where “‘the worms that eat them do not die, and the fire is not quenched.’[a] Why do these bother me? I have thought deeply about what it would be like to be the one who burns in Hell forever, and the thought of it happening to anyone, even my worst enemy, fills me with empathy, which is love. I cannot accept that infinite torture is ever acceptable morally. I consider it a sick and twisted thing to do, a thing that is infinitely worse than death, a sin of such magnitude it is the worst sin that could ever be committed, an infinitely evil abomination. I cannot accept that God is a monster who kills everyone who ever lived, even children, and then brutally tortures almost everyone on Earth forever. Most of all, it is the books of Genesis and Exodus that cause me to think the Bible must indeed have been written by ignorant ancients. There was never any Adam and Eve, or a fist human, according to evolution, which has been observed, and is therefore a fact. There was also never any Moses. He is a fictional character, and the stories about him are not true. There is simply no evidence where there should be mountains of it, and there are no records indicating the story is true where there should be many.

Still in elementary school I was starting to doubt things. Brought up in a household where justice was important, and being naive by nature, I was wondering why do so many people and animals die such tragic deaths they did not deserve - where is the justice in that? I love cats, and I’ve witnessed little kittens being run over by cars and my first cat get killed and tortured by the neighbour’s dog when I was 6 years old, as the neighbours did nothing to prevent or stop it from happening. As a child it brought me a lot of pain as I didn’t get WHY did these things happen to INNOCENT living beings. I started turning to religion, prayed every night for my family and pets to be ok - so I started reading the Bible, a special edition for kids. The quote that set me off was: Genesis 1:26 Then God said, “Let us make humankind in our image, according to our likeness; and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the wild animals of the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth.” As I’ve been reading the description of the sixth day, I remember thinking “ARE YOU KIDDING ME?! You’re telling me that an animal’s life is worth s**t??? You’re preaching that men are entitled to the whole planet, to do what they want with everything? I hate this!” and just closed the book and never continued reading. Also geography had some influence over my thoughts on heaven and hell. Like, where is this guy and why has noone seem him if he’s just above us? How can he hear and keep track of so many people praying at the same time on this huge planet?  For many years I’ve considered myself an atheist. It was a huge struggle as I was still in high school during this time and had noone to turn to for a meaningful conversation, spent my whole teenage years wondering what is even the meaning of life and should I just die and get it over with, and also didn’t believe in destiny - how I wished some things were avoided and that they weren’t meant to be. At 20, I’ve decided I don’t care anymore. So now I’m an apatheist. I have found many other reasons as my purpose for living - e.g. people I care about and art. As for destiny, I try not to think about it.

Seriously? That’s like asking what passages in the Wheel of Time trilogy (or better yet, the half dozen ‘continuing adventures of Al’Thor and friends’) made you an atheist. Get this, if Bible verses are deemed to have any authoritative influence over your theological position on the existence of God, you have to regard them as evidence for God. Otherwise, they are simply books that you regard as having only what truth value is in them by accident. People are atheists because they don’t want to believe in any God, not because they happen to disbelieve in a particular scriptural tradition. Anyone that believes in the God of the Bible is disbelieving in the divine portrayals of the Koran or the Vedas or whatever. Heck, the majority of people who believe in the portrayal of God in the New Testament have a habit of disbelieving in the God of the Old Testament. Everyone believes the truth claims of some ‘scriptures’ and disregards the claims of others. There are various atheist scriptures (or rather, writings basing their truth claims on the assumed superiority of atheism of some sort or other). If a person found a passage in an atheist work that, to them, definitively established the truth claims of that work, and thus the claims of atheism, that could make them an atheist. But finding your proof of the non-existence of God in one of the many claimed divine scriptures which put forth variant and incompatible ideas about God is intellectually unserious.

As a child, I read “bible stories” avidly, and never questioned the existence of god, until I started thinking about the story of Noah and the great flood, at the age of 6, when I began reading books about geography, geology and meteorology. I realized that the story of Noah could not be entirely reconciled with the emerging knowlege of the history of the world. This undermined the idea of biblical infallibility, which was promoted by the religion I was being raised in. Discovering that “Bible scholars” calculated that the Earth was only 6,000 years old was the last nail in that coffin. Either all of science was wrong, or at least part of the Bible was. The debate wasn’t really even close. The existence of god vanished, in my mind, with the discovery and splitting of the atom. If god created the world, and the “word of god” was written in the Bible, then how could there be no mention of atoms in the book? I recalled Santa and the Easter Bunny, and realized that adults routinely lie to children, in order to control their behavior. Since Easter bunny and Santa were proven to be fables, why should god not end up with them in the rubbish bin? On reflection, the so-called “passion” of Christ seemed like nothing but a mythic exposition of a political murder, transformed into martyrdom for chiefly political purposes. It wasn’t until I went to college that the Biblical rug was pulled out from under religion. There, I learned that the Bible was a compilation of ancient texts from many sources, which had been revised, translated and reinterpreted many times. Entire “books” had been added and removed at the whim of religious authorities. Divinely inspired “Word of God,” really? What god? Apparently just another fable. Caveat emptor.

God calls for child sacrifice: Genesis 22: 1–10 1 And it came to pass after these things, that God did tempt Abraham, and said unto him, Abraham: and he said, Behold, here I am. 2 And he said, Take now thy son, thine only son Isaac, whom thou lovest, and get thee into the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of. 3 And Abraham rose up early in the morning, and saddled his ass, and took two of his young men with him, and Isaac his son, and clave the wood for the burnt offering, and rose up, and went unto the place of which God had told him. 4 Then on the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes, and saw the place afar off. 5 And Abraham said unto his young men, Abide ye here with the ass; and I and the lad will go yonder and worship, and come again to you. 6 And Abraham took the wood of the burnt offering, and laid it upon Isaac his son; and he took the fire in his hand, and a knife; and they went both of them together. 7 And Isaac spake unto Abraham his father, and said, My father: and he said, Here am I, my son. And he said, Behold the fire and the wood: but where is the lamb for a burnt offering? 8 And Abraham said, My son, God will provide himself a lamb for a burnt offering: so they went both of them together. 9 And they came to the place which God had told him of; and Abraham built an altar there, and laid the wood in order, and bound Isaac his son, and laid him on the altar upon the wood. 10 And Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife to slay his son. EDIED TO ADDRESS COMMENTS: It is typical to explain away this horrific passage by explaining that God was “testing” Abraham and the very next describes the angel staying Abraham’s hand with the knife in it, so obviously, God wasn’t actually going ot go through with the test. There are multiple defects with these proffered apologetics. First, why did an all knowing god need to test Abraham? He already knew the depth of Abraham’s faith. Second, why was Abraham not surprised when he got such a gruesome request? Why didn’t he say, “WHAT DID YOU JUST ASK ME TO DO???” We know that that Abraham could question God’s commands and bargain with God. He did exactly that just before the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. Yet, when asked to sacrifice his only child, it’s no big deal, not a hint of resistance or doubt. My guess is that Abraham had no doubts because such a command could be reasonably made by the god worshipped by Abraham— a bloodthirsty god demanding child sacrifice. Next, nobody addresses Isaac in this situation. We know Isaac is old enough to assist his father and to infer that something important is apparently missing in the planned sacrificial event. WE also know that Isaac didn’t participate voluntarily in the process — he had to be tied down. What was going through Isaac’s head at this time? Love, contentment? How about abject terrror as he sees his father reading a knife to slay him. There are suggestions that perhaps Abraham and Issac knew that god would intervene. If that was true, the entire thing was a mere charade and not an example of Abraham’s faith because he knew there was a “king’s X somewhere. No matter how this episode is analyzed, the god demanded child sacrifice and inflicted extreme cruelty on Abraham and excruciating cruelty on an innocent boy.

I suppose this question comes from people like me stating repeatedly that this or that Bible verse contributed to their atheism. It was a lack of Bible verses, really, that lay at the centre of my deconversion. I searched the Bible, the hymns, the sermons—anything I could lay hands on—to understand what in the universe changed when Jesus died to make it possible for human souls to get into heaven. If I can forgive all the horrible things people have done to me without so much as an apology, then I know an almighty all-knowing merciful and loving God can and will forgive without anyone’s death unless it was absolutely necessary. An ancient Jewish custom of animal sacrifice did not justify the crucifixion. An all-knowing God could have come up with some means of salvation that made sense to Ancient Israel as well as late-twentieth-century people. The foregoing were my convictions, the only thing that made sense. That a dead body could somehow aid living human souls did not make sense on any level, not for me when I was a small child in the middle of the 20th century, nor when I was a theology student in the early 21st century. As in Plato’s forms, the spiritual is superior to the material; the dead body of Jesus was a physical body, material. Somehow, I knew all of this as a seven-year-old child. Yet Christianity said Jesus died so we could get to heaven. I trusted Christianity. I trusted my parents, teachers, and preachers. I knew of no other way to think of the universe, of human life, of death. Everything I had access to had a Christian slant. It was the way my brain had been taught to operate. But there was always the Contradiction. I could not rest until I had peace with it. I lived as Christians were supposed to live. Paul said that would bring peace. Isaiah said God would give peace. Jesus said the new birth would be mine. None of these things happened. Not until I disobeyed all the rules and took my life—and eternal salvation—into my own hands. It was the scariest thing I ever did. I don’t think I could go through that again. It took months, years, the best part of a decade to truly recover from the trauma. Just writing about it causes my heart to speed up. That’s how traumatic it was. It was worth it. No where in the Bible does God or Jesus or Paul or Moses or anyone for that matter write the answer I searched for. Yet Jesus promised in many different verses that all we had to do was ask and pray, and we’d get what we needed. Doesn’t work that way, my friend, not if you actually need something and it isn’t on the menu. Why God created me this way is not a question I ever got an answer to, either.

After a lifetime of being a committed Christian, albeit with inner questions, one very familiar verse suddenly hit me. Right upside the head. Actually, it irreparably smashed my faith wide fucking open. Ready? A sudden, unbidden, blasphemous thought came to my mind. So where did he go, outer space? I tried to force that thought to go away. But more came. No seriously, where did he go? Did he freeze to death at a certain altitude? Lose oxygen? Go behind a cloud, are you kidding me? You think Heaven is behind that cloud? That is an ANCIENT view of the world, and you are okay with this?! It was a shocking revelation at the time. I felt like I temporarily turned into the Gollum/Smeagol twins. There were definitely two sides of me fighting on the inside. I am now an atheist. The war is over.

That one’s quite easy…James 4:17 - “Therefore, to him that knoweth to do good and doeth it not, to him it is sin.” (King James) The belief in the need for salvation rests upon the belief in “original sin” passed down to all people as the result of Adam and Eve’s “sin of disobedience”. God supposedly commanded Adam and Eve not to partake of the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil and the Tree of Life. Eve, charmed by the snake, ate the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge and then convinced Adam to do the same, thus supposedly disobeying God…a “sin”. OK, so first, getting past the whole talking snake thing, let’s consider Adam and Eve’s “sin”. God did not want Adam and Eve to gain any knowledge of good and evil, the theological thinking being that if they gained that knowledge they would eventually sin and no longer be able to dwell in the presence of a perfect God. And therein lies the crux of the whole thing…prior to eating the fruit, Adam and Eve HAD NO KNOWLEDGE. James 4:17 clearly states that knowledge is necessary for an act to be classified by God as “sin”. The verse states that you have to KNOW that what you are doing is wrong. Absent any knowing, the direct inference is that the act is NOT a sin. Prior to eating the fruit, they could not have known that what they were doing was wrong. So, the argument goes, “But God told them not to eat, so they knew.” If that’s true, then God violated his own command to them and provided them with knowledge of good and evil, thus invalidating the command not to eat because he had already given them the very knowledge he didn’t want them to have. Finding one error just led to contemplate the myriad other contradictions and very shortly thereafter, voila, one more atheist.

Which Bible verses made you an atheist? The first one. Earth did not exist prior to any other celestial body. The Bible is wrong right from the very first verse. And the second one, which is a convoluted adaptation of prior scripture (Enuma Elish) And the third one. And the fourth. And the fifth... And the similarly ignorant verses of all the other scriptures I checked out. But all that is metaphorical, right?  Right! Scriptures are for the most part cutesy ancient literature. Merely good reads. A window on the past. All educated people agree they are not factual. (Or, do they?) What really made me an atheist is coming - or not coming - to grips with people who actually believe some of these ancient myths. Like, for example, the ‘incarnations’ or ‘arrivals’ of gods like Krishna, Dionysus, and Jesus. Or the resurrection of Osiris after having his body cut to pieces and scattered all over Egypt. Or the one about the young man-god who had to die a heinous and humiliating death in order for our sins to be forgiven even though he had already been forgiving sins before he died! Stories like these are nothing more than fairy tales for adults.

Or the presumption of divine influence over authorship is false.
